awd_titl_txt: The Influence of Sea Ice Motion on Antarctic Sea Ice Expansion
awd_abstract_narration:
Satellite observations show expanding Antarctic sea ice over the last three decades. Increasing Antarctic sea ice seems unexpected when compared to observations of rising global temperatures or shrinking Arctic sea ice. Computer models of global climate also predict Antarctic sea ice to shrink instead of grow. Several hypotheses have been suggested to explain the contradiction between what scientists expect to see based on computer models and physical intuition and the growth that is recorded in observations. This study will examine the hypothesis that sea ice expansion can be explained by sea ice motion, where sea ice moves in such a way as to promote an increase in overall coverage. Researchers will use several different types of computer models, ranging in complexity, to better understand the physical processes of sea ice motion and how the sea ice motion interacts with the larger atmosphere-ocean system. The team will transfer their research to the classroom by hosting a week-long teacher workshop. Teachers will learn how scientists use computer models to test hypotheses and then develop and test tools for use in the classroom. Five middle and high school teachers will participate and become part of the UC San Diego STEM Success Initiative master science teacher network. The project will support a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher.

Sea ice motion has recently emerged as one of the candidates to explain the Antarctic sea ice expansion but a systematic investigation of how sea ice motion influences sea ice concentration has not been presented to date. Researchers will conduct a process-oriented study of the relationship between sea ice motion and Antarctic sea ice extent using a hierarchy of models. The hierarchy will consist of (i) an idealized single-column model of sea ice evolution, (ii) an idealized latitudinally-varying global model of sea ice and climate, (iii) an atmospheric global climate model (GCM) above a slab ocean that includes sea ice motion, (iv) a comprehensive GCM, and (v) model output from the suite of current comprehensive GCMs. The range of model complexities will help researchers better understand the relationship between sea ice motion and sea ice extent by allowing them to identify important processes that are robust across the model hierarchy.

por.por_cntn:
Funded by this NSF award, we have investigated the connection between sea ice motion and sea ice areal cover, focusing on the hypothesis that the observed expansion of the Antarctic sea ice extent during much of the satellite record can be largely attributed to sea ice motion. We adopted a process-oriented approach that involved a hierarchy of models from idealized process models up to comprehensive atmosphere-ocean global climate models (GCMs). This research has also raised a number of related questions that we investigated using a range of tools.

Major findings of our research include the following:

(1) Using a GCM that simulated Antarctic sea ice retreat during recent decades of the historical period (like most current GCMs), we found that when we replaced the simulated sea ice motion with an estimate of the observed ice motion, the GCM approximately captured the observed Antarctic sea ice expansion. This suggests that the bias in Antarctic sea ice trends simulated with GCMs are largely due to simulation biases in the sea ice drift velocity, implying that an improved representation of sea ice motion is crucial for more accurate sea ice projections (Sun and Eisenman, 2021).

(2) We developed a framework for understanding the relationship between sea ice drift and sea ice area by using an idealized process model of sea ice and global climate with specified sea ice motion, and the results showed that it depends critically on factors including the season when the ice is drifting, the speed at which it drifts, and the background climate (Wagner, Eisenman, and Mason, 2021). In related work, we used a combination of laboratory flume tank experiments and theoretical calculations to develop a deeper understanding of how wind causes sea ice to drift, drawing a connection to the drift of other floating objects including icebergs, mangrove propagules, and oil slicks (Wagner, Eisenman, and Ceroli, in review).

(3) We also investigated how sea ice motion influences the seasonal cycle of Antarctic sea ice extent, which is strikingly asymmetric with a long period of gradual winter growth and a short period of rapid summer melt. Previous work had suggested that this asymmetry occurs due to the sea ice motion field in summer favoring fast ice retreat. We ultimately found evidence that this is not the case. Our results instead suggest that the seasonal asymmetry is driven by the seasonal structure of the top-of-atmosphere incident solar radiation (Roach, Eisenman, Wagner, Blanchard-Wrigglesworth, Bitz, in review).

Other research carried out under this project includes findings related to the Antarctic Slope Current (Si, Stewart, Eisenman, in review), phytoplankton blooms that occur near the sea-ice edge (Lester, Wagner, McNamara, and Cape, 2021), the rapid rate of Arctic sea ice retreat and relatedly the Arctic amplification of global warming (Beer, Eisenman, and Wagner, 2020; England, Eisenman, Lutsko, and Wagner, 2021; Beer and Eisenman, in review; Hahn, Armour, Battisti, Eisenman, Bitz, in review), the impact of sea ice changes on the global climate system (England, Eisenman, Wagner, in review), and the influence of sea ice and other surface forcing in the Southern Ocean on the global ocean overturning circulation (Sun, Eisenman, and Stewart, 2018; Sun, Eisenman, Zanna, and Stewart, 2020).

Overall, the work under this award has helped explain the relationship between sea ice motion and sea ice area, and it has helped determine why Antarctic sea ice expanded during much of the satellite era and why climate models fail to capture this expansion, building physical understanding and suggesting ways for model improvement.

The research under this award led to the submission of 24 peer-reviewed publications (18 published and 6 currently in review). One undergraduate student, three graduate students, and one visiting graduate student have been trained, fully or partially supported under this award. A postdoc who began working under this award has assumed a faculty position, continuing to work on this project and taking on an oversight role through a subaward.
